Fix üëâ: In Ethereum, strings and bytes are padded on the lower-order (right) side with zero-bytes, while other types (such as numbers and addresses) are padded on the higher-order side.

Thanks, @YBadiss for pointing this out to me

Erratum: In this thread, I tried to explain how types are stored by using the endian terminology. It was a mistake on my part, this is a misuse of the term endianness. I've now convinced the term "padded" fits better to explain how types are stored. https://t.co/ge1FVDKdjj

@YBadiss As you can see, the first and last parameters (uint and bool types) are filled using the Little-Endian method but the string value is filled using the Big-Endian method

The event: https://t.co/K0YghyqqfD

@YBadiss However, the value 0x64636261 would be stored 0x00000...64636261 in its storage slot using the Little Endian method.

Don't trust me, verify. I created a dump smart contract and triggered an event with some indexed values.

Contract: 
https://t.co/RD1e5QxIsX

@YBadiss All other types are stored using Little Endian values, in which case leading zeros are added.
Regarding 0x64636261, it will look like it is simply saved as 64636261 because the EVM will convert the hexadecimal value for you when using it.

@YBadiss All variables are stored in hexadecimal in the storage location, it is important to know.
Strings and bytes are stored using Big Endian methods, which means that 0 bits are added to the end of the value to fill the slot.

@YBadiss I'm not sure I understand what you mean, so feel free to let me know if I don't answer your question. You are correct, the storage slots are 256-bit words. In this slot, single values are paddled and multiple values are packed where possible.

The EVM uses both methods, Big Endian is used to store string/bytes types and the Little Endian is used to store all other types like (u)int, addresses...

This is important to understand, especially if you plan to do some bytes operations in Solidity. Happy coding üí™

4/4 https://t.co/UKO9PbEJSQ

When using Big Endian, the **first** byte of the binary representation of the multibyte data type is stored first. 

Unlike Big Endian, when using Little Endian the **last** byte of the binary representation of the multibyte data type is stored first.

3/4

When talking about multi-byte data types (int, float, etc)  there are two ways of storing, the little Endian way and the Big Endian

2/4

In computing, the endianness corresponds to how bytes are stored/ordered. It defines the internal ordering of the memory. Let's see how bytes are stored/ordered in Solidity.
https://t.co/FT07XUjKOR

1/4

Do you know you can return multiple values from a function in Solidity? Solidity internally allows tuple types, a list of objects of potentially different types whose number is a constant at compile-time. Those tuples can be used to return multiple values at the same time. https://t.co/gYA9tIyurx

The "web3" is stateful, the "web2" is stateless, this is to my eyes THE valuable difference that we branded metaverse for marketing purposes. VR is just a random entry point to this decentralized "database"   3/3
The interoperability is a property resulting from the fact that "web3" is the "web2" network on which we plugged a decentralized "database"    2/3

Stop saying that metaverse is only about VR, we won't progress like that, it's the same delirium as NFT is only about art, what a misunderstanding. In both cases, we forget that the real revolution comes from interoperability    1/3

we talk a lot about the optimal way to pack variables here but don't forget that 
- Structs and array data always start a new slot 
- Items following struct or array data always start a new storage slot Choose wisely where you declare your structs and arrays

This is it, now you know how the two opcodes dedicated to the creation of new smart contracts work. Think of the CREATE2 opcode the next time you want to send ETHs to a new contract avoiding the front-running attack.

As you can see, the future address calculation function accepts 4 arguments. 0xFF which is a constant that prevents collisions with CREATE, the address of the sender, a salt which is an arbitrary value provided by the sender and the bytecode of the contract to deploy

This is exactly what the CREATE2 opcode is for.  Using it, the resulting address is independent of future events, you can send ETH to a pre-calculated address and then deploy the contract, whenever you want, and interact with the current balance https://t.co/s0sYKTeTGF

This means that smart contract addresses are predictable, awesome, right? However, using the nonce is not practical, you have to predict the exact nonce you will get when you deploy a contract. Wouldn't it be great to be able to predict contract addresses without using the nonce?

The CREATE opcode is the one used to deploy a new contract. Whether the contract is deployed by an EOA or another smart contract, the contract address will be calculated from the sender address and the account nonce. https://t.co/g04HtRChGD
